abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Herbert Stavely Sammond (1871-1964) was a Brooklyn-based organist, choral leader, and music teacher whose career spanned over 70 years. The Hebert Stavely Sammond papers, dating from 1885 to 1964 (bulk dates 1891 to 1958) and measuring 1.67 linear feet, constitute a personal record of Sammond's musical activity. Materials represented in the collection include correspondence, scrapbooks, clippings, writings, scores, sheet music, concert programs, and one black and white photograph of Sammond. Materials relating to the Morning Choral Society, Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, and the Middle Collegiate Church are included in the collection. Further, Sammond's own musical compositions and arrangements can also be found in the collection.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Herbert Stavely Sammond papers, 1977.245, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Gift of Mrs. Herbert S. Sammond, 1964.

Sammond did not limit his activities solely to the console. During World War I he acquired a military job as the Song Leader of forts in Brooklyn, Staten Island, and Rockaway County. He granted private music lessons and served as conductor of several choral organizations, including the Flushing Oratorio, the Elizabeth (New Jersey) Oratorio Society, the Apollo Men's Club of Asbury Park (New Jersey), and most famously of all, the Morning Choral Society of Brooklyn. The Morning Choral Society was founded in 1919 by Sammond as a women's amateur vocal group. Over the years it gained an esteemed reputation among the churchgoing citizens of Brooklyn, and his retirement from the group in 1949 met with fanfare and local media attention. The Morning Choral Society eventually disbanded in 1962, two years before Sammond's death.

Series 1: Professional Activities and Affiliations 0.42 Linear feet in eight folders. 1895-1962 Scope and Contents

This series contains papers and photographs that document Sammond's activities as an organist, conductor, teacher, and occasional journalist. They vary in nature from concert programs, to notepads inscribed with copious preparatory notes and private lesson plans, to correspondence. Of particular interest are items found among Sammond's writings. These include a typescript of his autobiographical sketch Seventy Years at the Console, a printed version of the sketch, and also typescripts of articles he placed in music periodicals such as The American Organist and which he may have used to give lectures. The eight black and white photographic prints primarily relate to Sammond's activities as an organist and conductor.

 Series 2: Memorabilia 0.42 Linear feet in one manuscript box. 1891-1964 Scope and Contents

The materials in this series function together as memorabilia, compiled presumably by Sammond himself. They consist of two scrapbooks and a folder of newspaper and magazine clippings--all of which are in fragile condition. The clippings offer a wide-ranging view of the local media attention garnered by Sammond and his musical activities over the decades. Clippings are also present in the two scrapbooks. Scrapbook 1 is a bound volume with recital and church programs, as well as a pictorial list of churches at which Sammond served as organist and choirmaster. Scrapbook 2 is unbound and primarily commemorates Sammond's 1949 retirement from the Morning Choral Society. To that effect, it contains appreciative telegrams and letters.

 Series 3: Music Compilations 0.31 Linear feet in four folders. 1889-1953 Scope and Contents

This series contains sheet music of various composers including a volume of organ works of J.S. Bach, a volume of Mozart's piano sonatas, and a volume of modern organ music, among others. Some of the sheet music has notations made by Sammond.

 Series 4: Music Compositions 0.52 Linear feet in one and one quarter manuscript boxes. 1915-1958 Scope and Contents

This series contains music by Sammond himself. In this series a distinction is made between original, handwritten scores and printed sheet music; it is arranged according to these two formats and sub-arranged alphabetically by the titles of Sammond's individual compositions. The compositions themselves are original works in certain ways: in some instances Sammond appropriates a poem or a set of lyrics authored by someone else and scores his own music to the words. In other instances he composes a unique arrangement of the work of another composer. All the scores are undated, but when both a score(s) and sheet music exist for a single composition, the corresponding date is provided on account of the copyright on the sheet music.
